title: 103_hr5091
content: The "Economic Growth and Jobs Act of 1994" may provide tax relief in the event of low growth. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 3% and national unemployment is above 6.0% for specific testing periods. After notification of economic indicators, the President may authorize temporary tax reductions for a specified calendar year to stimulate the economy. The declaration must be transmitted to Congress for approval. The President can authorize temporary tax reductions for a specific calendar year to stimulate the economy. The tax rates for the first income bracket in the tax tables will be reduced by a percentage specified in the declaration, and the tax amounts in the tables will be adjusted accordingly. The President can authorize temporary tax reductions for a specific calendar year to stimulate the economy. Withholding tables will be modified to reflect the full calendar year effect of the reduction through withholding reductions after the declaration. Temporary surtax may apply if economic growth requirements are met in the subsequent year. The President can authorize temporary tax reductions for a specific calendar year to stimulate the economy. Withholding tables will be modified to reflect the full calendar year effect of the reduction through withholding adjustments. Tax rates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by a certain percentage for the year, and tax amounts in the tables will be adjusted accordingly. The tax rates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be modified to reflect the increase in tax rates for the year. The economic growth requirements for the calendar year include a GDP growth of over 4% and a national unemployment rate below 6.0%. The percentage increase in tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is determined by the President to offset any decrease in receipts. The percentage will be published in the Federal Register before the start of the calendar year. Special rules apply if there are multiple rate reductions before an increase. The percentage increase in tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is determined by the President to offset any decrease in receipts. Special rules apply for subsequent calendar years to determine the percentage decrease in receipts. SEC. 3. Treatment under pay-as-you-go procedures: Any change in receipts from this Act will not be considered under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
